componenttextpreview: We actually don't know that. We only get volume numbers at this point, and share doesn't come along for a couple of more weeks. I would say that we are certainly benefiting from some warm weather in the major eastern markets. During the second quarter, we
componenttext: We actually don't know that. We only get volume numbers at this point, and share doesn't come along for a couple of more weeks. I would say that we are certainly benefiting from some warm weather in the major eastern markets. During the second quarter, we also had some poor weather in Western Canada, which has corrected itself. So, very difficult to give you a breakdown at this point.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, Stewart, just in terms of - any updated thoughts on your free cash flow generation this year? Obviously, you know, we are half way through the year, and then, just in terms of the use going forward, you know, obviously you have taken care
componenttext: Okay. And then, Stewart, just in terms of - any updated thoughts on your free cash flow generation this year? Obviously, you know, we are half way through the year, and then, just in terms of the use going forward, you know, obviously you have taken care of the Brazilian tax liability. In the past, you have talked about maybe shoring up the pension issue. Any updated thoughts there would be helpful.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks for that, Judy. I would just start by saying obviously, we are really pleased with how our first half cash generation has gone; and I would echo the comments that I have made before in terms of our strict financial discipline in terms of looki
componenttext:
Yes, thanks for that, Judy. I would just start by saying obviously, we are really pleased with how our first half cash generation has gone; and I would echo the comments that I have made before in terms of our strict financial discipline in terms of looking at the use of cash, in terms of either investing in the business, bolstering our balance sheet, or sharing cash with shareholders, and I - taking a look back at the first half, you pointed to a couple of things. You will see some of that behavior actually in practice, you know, in terms of investing in the business, you saw us close the Granville deal. We have invested toward a joint venture in China, and we have obviously invested behind MillerCoors to try to guard some of the synergies. So, we have seen a fair bit of business investment.
As you have also pointed out, we did take a step in this past quarter to resolve the Brazilian tax credit issue, and that, we spent roughly $100 million, and we increased the dividend in the last quarter. So, you know, as we look forward, we will continue to consider all of those, pensions among them, and we will use the same kind of discipline that we had used in the first half.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. What we are seeing from the consumer is number one, an interest in innovation, which is really encouraging. So, you know, I think the news value that comes along with new ideas is resonating with consumers. We are seeing people, you know, continuing
componenttext: Yes. What we are seeing from the consumer is number one, an interest in innovation, which is really encouraging. So, you know, I think the news value that comes along with new ideas is resonating with consumers. We are seeing people, you know, continuing to keep a pretty tight grip on their wallet. So, you know, industry year-to-date is up 0.4%. Not a bad performance, but clearly not at the historic level that we would have seen, and you see consumers continuing to show an interest in the value offerings and that is not really a change. The thing that encourages me most is to see the interest we are seeing in the innovation front.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, through the first six months of the year, we have taken some level of price in nine of our provinces. So it is fairly extensive. It is focused on different SKUs, we are looking at where we believe there are revenue opportunities by brand. So for ins
componenttext: Well, through the first six months of the year, we have taken some level of price in nine of our provinces. So it is fairly extensive. It is focused on different SKUs, we are looking at where we believe there are revenue opportunities by brand. So for instance, Molson Canadian 67, which you will remember we launched in our fourth quarter, we recently - I mean, about three of our markets taken that to a 5% premium, over the mainstream brands, that would be an example of the sort of thing we are doing. Miller Chill, which is performing well as a line entry in the market, we have held firm on pricing, which is taking our share of value up on that brand as we see competitors dropping their prices somewhat. So, holding firm there. It is generally an orientation to grab through the revenue opportunities that we identify.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. So that is kind of historically speaking, if we think about September, when we often see price increases, and some of that has been getting dealt back. I mean, do you think there is an opportunity in Quebec to take some pricing and have it kind of s
componenttext: Okay. So that is kind of historically speaking, if we think about September, when we often see price increases, and some of that has been getting dealt back. I mean, do you think there is an opportunity in Quebec to take some pricing and have it kind of show up for the consumer as well, or do you think we are still in a tough enough competitive and consumer environment where that really can't happen?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it is really hard for me to predict the outcome, obviously, Mark, but clearly, you know, we will be looking for the opportunities, continue to look for the opportunities that are out there for us. You know, as to whether they will stick, that is som
componenttext: Well, it is really hard for me to predict the outcome, obviously, Mark, but clearly, you know, we will be looking for the opportunities, continue to look for the opportunities that are out there for us. You know, as to whether they will stick, that is something to be determined in the future.

And relating to its brand equity, do you think that the brand equity is strong enough here to hold both market share and price parity next year, given the pricing environment and the outlook that we are expecting from AVI?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. We have got Tom Long on the phone. So I will ask him to comment in detail, but just as a sort of general overview, you know, we have been encouraged by the sequential improvements in Miller Lite. When you talk about the brand house scores, again, To
componenttext: Sure. We have got Tom Long on the phone. So I will ask him to comment in detail, but just as a sort of general overview, you know, we have been encouraged by the sequential improvements in Miller Lite. When you talk about the brand house scores, again, Tom can talk in detail about that, but the ones that we regard as the most important are moving in the right direction. We have been helped by some channel mix as well, but we always said this is going to be a long term turnaround, but we are encouraged with the progress we are making, I think, and (inaudible). Tom, can you answer that?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. You know, the metrics as we have talked about on for brand equity, behavioral and attitude on Miller Lite, have been improving sequentially. It is the channel where it has most relative strength, as you know, is on-premise, which has been the segment
componenttext: Yes. You know, the metrics as we have talked about on for brand equity, behavioral and attitude on Miller Lite, have been improving sequentially. It is the channel where it has most relative strength, as you know, is on-premise, which has been the segment that it has had the most improvement in volume and which is encouraging. And we are not ready to call that brand turned around, Carlos, but you will also know that that is the brand in the portfolio we have actually raised price most on since the beginning of the JV.

componenttext: Carlos, we are not going to talk about pricing going forward. I think what we are saying is that we are comfortable with the brand performance, where it is. It is slow in sequential improvement, but that is exactly what we expected and we have seen some good indicators in terms of the brand health and we are very satisfied with that position.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Look, I think I might just reinforce the point I made earlier, which is, we have got three ways of deploying cash, which is investing in the business, bolstering our balance sheet, or sharing cash with shareholders; and the point at which any one of
componenttext: Yes. Look, I think I might just reinforce the point I made earlier, which is, we have got three ways of deploying cash, which is investing in the business, bolstering our balance sheet, or sharing cash with shareholders; and the point at which any one of those raises its head above the parapet is really dependent on that point of time; and every quarter, we go through a cash planning cycle, we use a strict financial discipline and what we think is the best return for shareholders where we deploy the cash.

componenttext: Thank you very much. I had a question on the U.K., if I could. Looking at your volume growth of 0.7%, and then the share gains in the off-premise channel, I wonder if you can describe for us the dynamics in the on-premise, wondering if the World Cup had a different impact on that channel, and what was it that suggests a loss of market share there?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks for the question. I think the interesting thing, just as a reminder, is if you look at the second quarter on an industry level, obviously the industry had a strong second quarter. But all of that growth came in the month of June, where the of
componenttext: Sure. Thanks for the question. I think the interesting thing, just as a reminder, is if you look at the second quarter on an industry level, obviously the industry had a strong second quarter. But all of that growth came in the month of June, where the off-premise grew by round about 30% in that month, that is from an STR perspective. So most of the benefit from both improved weather and the World Cup really came through the off-premise channel. Within on-premise, we have seen really a continuation of underlying trends, whereas on-premise is continuing to decline at round about 6% or 7%. So no real significant change, and the channel that really won most on the back of the World Cup and the weather was certainly the off-premise, but principally in the month of June, first couple of months of the quarter weren't significantly better than the trends that we had seen earlier in the year.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, in terms of our share trends in on-premise, I think we mentioned last year that we have, on the back of our value over volume strategy, basically come out of a couple of major customers. We are about to start cycling that volume loss, and we are ver
componenttext: Well, in terms of our share trends in on-premise, I think we mentioned last year that we have, on the back of our value over volume strategy, basically come out of a couple of major customers. We are about to start cycling that volume loss, and we are very pleased the way Carling is performing in on premise. Its throughputs are holding up very strongly. It is continuing to grow distribution, and we will start to cycle a couple of the major customer losses that we had last year. The general pricing on the brand has been very, very strong, and that is very much in line with our value ahead of volume strategy.

And you know, and looking for any color you are getting from what you are hearing from Washington.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, so we just talk about income taxes, and not excise taxes. I think that, you know, from where we sit, we think that if the range is a good range, it is very difficult at this point in time, Mark, as you pointed out for me to say, will we be at
componenttext: Yes. I mean, so we just talk about income taxes, and not excise taxes. I think that, you know, from where we sit, we think that if the range is a good range, it is very difficult at this point in time, Mark, as you pointed out for me to say, will we be at the low or high end of the range. I think that is part of the reason for the range. You will also notice that there has been a fair degree of volatility, depending on the year and depending on various, you know, tax actions that we take. We believe based on the current, you know, vocals we have heard from Washington that we are well prepared for the changes that could take place, and that given what we have heard, that this range looks good. Now, if something new comes up, obviously then we will provide that guidance at that time. But for the moment, we feel confident.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Before we get started, I want to paraphrase the company's Safe Harbor language. Some of the discussion today may include forward-looking statements. Actual results could differ materially from what the company projects today, so please refer to its most r
componenttext:
Before we get started, I want to paraphrase the company's Safe Harbor language. Some of the discussion today may include forward-looking statements. Actual results could differ materially from what the company projects today, so please refer to its most recent 10-K and 10-Q filing for a more complete description of factors that could affect those projections. The company does not undertake to publicly update forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. You should not place undue reliance on forward-looking statements, which speak only as of the date they are made. Regarding any non-U.S. GAAP measures that may be discussed during the call and from time to time by the company's executives in discussing the company's performance, please visit the website, www.molsoncoors.com, and click on the Financial Reporting tab of the Investor Relations page for the reconciliation of these measures to the nearest U.S. GAAP results. 
Now I would like to turn the call over to Peter Swinburn, President and CEO of Molson Coors. Mr. Swinburn, you may begin.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Devon, and hello, everybody, and welcome. Thanks for joining us today. With me on the call this morning are Stewart Glendinning, MillerCoors' Chief Financial Officer; Leo Kiely, CEO of MillerCoors; Gavin Hattersley, Chief Financial Officer of M
componenttext:
Thank you, Devon, and hello, everybody, and welcome. Thanks for joining us today. With me on the call this morning are Stewart Glendinning, MillerCoors' Chief Financial Officer; Leo Kiely, CEO of MillerCoors; Gavin Hattersley, Chief Financial Officer of MillerCoors; Dave Perkins, the CEO of Molson Coors Canada; Mark Hunter, the CEO of Molson Coors U.K.; Kandy Anand, President Molson Coors International; Sam Walker, Molson Coors' Chief Legal Officer; Bill Walters, MillerCoors' Controller; and Dave Dunnewald, Molson Coors' Vice President of Investor Relations. 
On the earnings call today, Stewart and I will share highlights of Molson Coors Brewing Company's third quarter 2010 results and along with some perspectives on the fourth quarter. Then we will open it up for questions. 
So in the third quarter, Molson Coors reported strong results. Underlying pretax income grew almost 30%, driven by double-digit earnings growth in the U.S., U.K. and in Canada. Each of these businesses achieved positive pricing, substantial cost reductions and significant market expansion in the quarter. Although we anticipate that some of the drivers of our third quarter pretax income growth will not carry over to the fourth quarter or will be used in the fourth quarter, these results represent a very solid third quarter for Molson Coors. 
Total company underlying after-tax earnings increased 12.3%, driven by strong pretax results, partially offset by higher tax rate this year. In the U.S., MillerCoors reduced cost of goods sold a hectoliter, which along with positive pricing, drove underlying income growth of more than 34%. In Canada, we achieved positive pricing in a weak market and still gained share and grew underlying profit by more than 16%.  And in the U.K., we continue to achieve robust pricing and cost reductions to drive a 12.6% underlying profit growth. Our sharp focus on brands, innovation and cost delivered these results. 
Regarding brands, our Canada business translated its extensive brand building activities over the past year into market share growth and an increase in net pricing in the quarter. In the U.S., Blue Moon, [indiscernible] and Coors Light grew share for MillerCoors, and Miller Lite trends improved sequentially in the quarter. 
In addition, we will begin importing, selling and marketing the Modelo brands in the U.K. and Japan beginning in January. The addition of Corona and other great Modelo brands will strengthen our portfolios in these two beer markets. And also in the third quarter, our International team improved volume more than 11% and completed the formation of our joint venture in China, which will reduce costs and allow us to leverage our best global innovations of Coors Light in the world's largest beer market. 
On costs, in the third quarter, we again exceeded our cost reduction targets with $24 million of RFG2 savings and $83 million of MillerCoors cost reductions. These cost reductions were a primary driver of lower cost of goods per hectoliter in Canada and the U.S. as well as expanded gross margins in these businesses and in the U.K. The weak global economy has presented substantial challenges for our company during the past several quarters. But during this time, we have stayed sharply focused on our strategies of building brands, driving value from innovation and delivering on our cost-saving commitments. 
By focusing on these strategies, we have increased profits, we have improved our margins, we generated substantial cash and we strengthened our balance sheet. In fact, our strong cash flow so far this year is allowing us to increase our free cash flow target for 2010. Also during the third quarter, we began to unwind our swap positions related to the positive stock and to lock in significant gains on the position that were still open. The remaining swap positions will mature by January 2011. More on these topics in a few minutes. 
So at this point, I'll turn it over to Stewart to review our third quarter financial results and business highlights. Then we'll cover the outlook for the fourth quarter, including our increased cash flow target for 2010. Stewart?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Peter. Hello, everyone. I'll start with the third quarter financial highlights. On the bottom line, underlying after-tax income of $239.1 million or $1.28 per diluted share increased 12.3% from a year ago due to higher net sales revenues, potentia
componenttext:
Thanks, Peter. Hello, everyone. I'll start with the third quarter financial highlights. On the bottom line, underlying after-tax income of $239.1 million or $1.28 per diluted share increased 12.3% from a year ago due to higher net sales revenues, potential cost reductions, higher equity income for MillerCoors and favorable foreign exchange. These positive factors more than offset the impact of lower volume in the U.K. and U.S. in a higher tax rate this year. Underlying pretax income grew 29.9% with about 1/4 of this growth attributable to timing and factors that we do not expect to da repeat or that will reverse in the fourth quarter. 
In the third quarter, we grew total company gross margins as well as operating and after-tax margins. In fact, we expanded gross margins more than two percentage points in the U.S., U.K. and Canada, which drove three percentage points of margin expansion of a total company basis for the quarter. And we achieved this margin expansion despite a 4% decline in our worldwide beer volume from a year ago. 
It is important to note that our third quarter underlying earnings exclude some non-core gains and expenses primarily related to changes in the value of our Foster's cash-settled total-return swap as well as net special charges of $3.1 million. These adjustments to our U.S. GAAP results are described in detail in the earnings release we distributed this morning. Also, unless otherwise indicated, all financial results we share with you today will be in U.S. dollars, and results comparisons will be versus the comparable prior year period. 
In segment performance highlights, starting with Canada. Underlying pretax income in local currency increased 9.9% in the third quarter. Continued volume growth, positive net pricing and cost of goods sold reductions in the quarter were partially offset by higher overhead expenses this year. In U.S. dollars, Canada underlying pretax income increased 16.1% to $162 million in the third quarter, which includes an $8 million benefit of a 6% year-over-year increase in the Canadian dollar versus the U.S. dollar. 
So let's review some highlights. Our Canada sales to retail or STRs for the calendar quarter ended September 30 increased 0.4% versus the prior year. Volume gained from new brands, including Molson M and Keystone, were offset by declines in our established brands. Our new brands, along with the addition of Granville Island volume, helped us to increase our market share nearly a full share point versus a year ago. Coors Light and Molson Canadian brands declined at low to mid- single digits in the quarter, as we adjusted price and volume priorities for these brands. 
Total Canadian beer industry sales to retail decreased an estimated 1.8% in the calendar third quarter primarily due to colder weather than a year ago, particularly in September, when the industry was down more than 6%. Our Canada sales volume was 2.5 million hectoliters in the third quarter, up 2.5%. Net sales per hectoliter increased 0.8% in local currency, driven by selective price increases taken during the year in all regions. Also, we have now cycled our less competitive pricing positions in the previous year. 
Cost sold per hectoliter decreased 4.5% in local currency in the third quarter, driven by the net effect of three factors. First, savings from our RFG2 cost reduction program reduced cost of goods sold per hectoliter by about 2.5 percentage points. Second, immaterial out of period adjustment to distribution and certain other costs decreased our rate by three percentage points. And third, these savings are partially offset by higher input costs, which increased cost of goods sold rate by about one percentage point. Marketing, general and administrative expense in the quarter increased 6.7% in local currency, driven primarily by increases in commercial- and employee-related expenses, along with the addition of Granville Island overhead costs. 
Moving to our U.K. business. In the third quarter, underlying pretax income increased 19.6% in local currency, driven by pricing in cost reductions. These positive factors were partially offset by the impact of lower volume. These results include a $7 million non-cash increase in defined benefit pension expense this year and a $3.6 million benefit as a result of cycling a 2009 mark-to-market charge on natural gas hedges. Our third quarter U.K. results were adversely impacted by $2 million due to a 6% devaluation of the British pound versus the U.S. dollar. And U.S. dollars underlying pretax income of $36.7 million represented an increase of $4.1 million or 12.6%. 
Looking at third quarter highlights for the U.K. Our U.K. own brand volume declined 12.5% in the quarter driven primarily by retailer destocking following the fee for World Cup, which ended early in our fiscal third quarter. Total U.K. beer industry volume decreased approximately 10% in the third quarter. Net sales per hectoliter of our own brands increased 11% in local currency with about eight percentage points driven by higher pricing and three percentage points as a result of positive sales mix maybe due to the impact of channel and brand mix. 
Cost of goods sold per hectoliter of our own brands increased 2% in local currency driven by the following factors. First, the incremental pension expense represented three percentage points of this increase. Second, two percentage points are due to mix, predominantly more cover sales this year. Third, four percentage points were attributable to fixed cost deleverage from lower own brand volumes. These were partly offset by a three-percentage-point reduction relating to cycling a mark-to-market adjustment on natural gas hedges in 2009 and a 4% point reduction from cost savings and input cost deflation. Marketing, general and administrative expenses in the U.K. increased 1% in local currency, reflecting higher pension expense this year, partly offset by lower marketing expense, which is expected to reverse in the fourth quarter. 
In our U.S. segment, underlying pretax income increased 34.2% to $144.1 million in the third quarter, driven by MillerCoors' results. Looking at the total MillerCoors P&L, third quarter underlying net income increased 36.7% to $334 million due to favorable pricing and continued synergy and cost savings delivery, which were partially offset by lower volume. MillerCoors' domestic STRs declined 4% driven by a sluggish U.S. beer market affecting the entire industry. Domestic sales to wholesalers declined 2.7%. Sales to wholesalers outperformed STRs largely due to distributing inventory build ahead of this year's full price increases. 
Total net revenue increased 0.3% to $2 billion. Pricing remained strong, however, as domestic net revenue per hectoliter, which excludes contract brewing and company-owned distributor sales, increased 2.4% in the quarter. Cost of goods sold per hectoliter decreased 0.3% due to the realization of synergies from supply chain and procurement, partially offset by higher transportation and packaging costs and the addition of brands purchased earlier this year by our Denver distributorship. Marketing and general and administration expenses decreased by 9.8% primarily driven by synergies and other cost savings. 
In our International and Corporate segment, the underlying pretax cost per International and Corporate combined was $54.6 million in the third quarter, a decrease of $3 million driven primarily by lower Corporate project and employee compensation expense this year. Third quarter Corporate net interest expense increased $0.8 million, and Corporate G&A expense decreased $3.6 million to $24.5 million. Our International team grew sales volume 11.2% in the third quarter, driven by sales in China and Europe. MG&A expense for International was $14.3 million in the quarter, an increase of $1.6 million due to brand investments and growth initiatives in our priority International markets. Corporate other income was $43.4 million, driven by a $42.3 million mark-to-market gain related to the total return swap we arranged with respective Foster's common stock. As usual, mark-to-market gains and losses on the Foster's swap are excluded from our underlying earnings. 
Now highlights of our cost-reduction initiatives. We exceeded our RFG2 program goals in the third quarter were $24 million cost savings towards the program's three-year goal of $150 million. In addition to our RFG2 savings, MillerCoors delivered $56 million of incremental cost synergies and $27 million of other cost reductions in the third quarter. We benefit from 42% of the MillerCoors' cost savings. Year-to-date, we delivered $55 million against our three-year RFG2 program goal of $150 million, and MillerCoors has achieved $216 million of synergies and other cost savings year-to-date. 
Moving beyond our operating business unit performance. Our third quarter effective tax rate was 19% on a reported basis and 17% on an underlying basis, up from 9% and 4%, respectively, a year ago. With regard to our balance sheet. Total debt at the end of the third quarter was $1.45 billion, and cash and cash equivalents totaled $764 million, resulting in net debt of $684 million. Our debt and cash balances were both temporarily low at the end of the third quarter, as we were in the process of refinancing $300 million of notes that matured in September. Our debt issuance in early October totaled CAD $500 million to give us a headroom for general Corporate purposes, which may include payments to fund our global pension obligations. 
Underlying free cash flow for the first three quarters of this year were $671 million, up from $534 million a year ago. Our cash generation this year was made up of $726 million of operating cash flow, plus $34 million of exceptional cash usage that we add back and $4 million of proceeds from asset sales minus $78 million of capital spending and $15 million of that net cash contributed to MillerCoors. 
Our cash flow for the first three quarters of 2010 was driven primarily by higher net income, some non-recurring cash flow sources and lower net investment of cash in MillerCoors this year. Please see our website for details regarding our adjustments to arrive at underlying free cash flow. 
Looking forward, we're increasing our 2010 underlying free cash flow target from $760 million to $900 million plus or minus 5%. This increase in our target is primarily due to some non-recurring cash flow sources this year, including our cash-settled total-return swap, our low cash taxes, a onetime improvement in U.K. working capital and proceeds from the repayment of a loan that MillerCoors had extended to past. 
One of our sources of cash in the fourth quarter will be the settlement of a portion of our swap positions related to the Foster's stock. As Peter mentioned, during the third quarter we locked in gains on the swaps and began to close out these positions. As of the end of the third quarter, we closed out swap positions representing exposure to $16 million Foster shares out of $90.1 million shares of exposure outstanding at the beginning of the third quarter. As of November 1, we had settled approximately 40% of the Foster's related swaps. Lots of these swaps will mature by January 2011. 
Regarding the uses of free cash. Among our usual range of opportunities, we're looking at full accelerated contributions to one or more of our defined benefit pension plans, which we expect to result in the fourth quarter. Anything we do will be prudent, measured and in the best interest of our shareholders. 
In terms of P&L outlook, we continue to expect full year 2010 MG&A expense in International Corporate segment of approximately $180 million, plus or minus 5%. We forecast full year 2010 Corporate interest expense to be approximately $105 million at today's foreign exchange rates. 
Turning to our effective tax rate. We expect our full year underlying rate for 2010 to be in the range of 15% to 17% assuming no changes in tax laws. This indicates a much higher tax rate than in the fourth quarter this year than last year's unusually lower rate, which benefited from the favorable resolution of unrecognized tax positions. We call that our fourth quarter 2009 tax rate was negative 65% on a reported basis and negative 54% on an underlying basis. We continue to forecast that are normalized long-term tax rate to be in the range of 22% to 26%. Our 2010 capital spending outlook remains approximately $150 million for the full year. And as always, this guidance excludes MillerCoors'. 
At this point, I'll turn it back over to Peter for a look ahead to the fourth quarter. Peter?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Stewart. In the fourth quarter, our focus will continue to be on brand building, innovation and reducing cost to cost of company. In Canada, we are encouraged by our volume in market share results with our share continuing to increase versus the p
componenttext:
Thanks, Stewart. In the fourth quarter, our focus will continue to be on brand building, innovation and reducing cost to cost of company. In Canada, we are encouraged by our volume in market share results with our share continuing to increase versus the prior year. These results are being driven by our brand led focus, including the product innovations we initiated towards the end of 2009 and early this year namely Molson M, Keystone and Keystone Light, Molson Canadian 67 and the Rickard's star brand extension. 
Additionally, this fall, we relaunched the most Molson Export brand with new positioning, advertising and packaging in Québec. Regarding Canada pricing, we've implemented selective price increases this year in all regions. We have also closed some price gaps on specific brands and packages in Ontario and the world far this year, and we will continue to evaluate price gaps in the fourth quarter to ensure we are competitive in these markets. 
In the U.K., the team continues to make substantial progress in improving profitability to our value ahead of volume strategy, and nearly all major on-premise customers' contracts are in place with annual price increases included. Looking forward, we anticipate lower U.K. net sales per hectoliter growth in the fourth quarter than in the past several quarters, primarily due to sighting the implementation of most of our new trading arrangements along with less positive channel and brand mix. We also expect significantly higher U.K. marketing promotional expense in the fourth quarter due in part to quarterly timing differences. 
Looking ahead in the U.S., we are committed to driving efficiency and strong pricing, but we are also committed to driving growth to an ever sharper focus on the things that really move the business and investing behind those drivers. You've seen it in our creation of five regions, a move that shifts our people resources to the local markets where we need to focus to win. You've seen it with the creation of [indiscernible], which we formed earlier this year. This company within a company has the capability and the focus to really drive our [indiscernible] portfolio. And the numbers show we're well on our way to doing that. 
We're also focusing on innovation to drive our premium lights. We've seen the vortex bottle improved trends from Miller Lights, hoping to drive a 6% improvement into inner light bottles. And the cold activated window pack help Coors Light continue to grow market share. Early returns show that the aluminum paint is also a hedge. 
As we look to 2011 in the U.S., we are going to focus on fewer, better ideas that will really drive the business in areas like single-serve, cost merchandising, aluminum seasonals, expanding soccer programs, continued innovation in premium lights and distribution. 
So the following of the most recent volume trends in each of our businesses early in the fourth quarter. In Canada, our sales to retail for the full weeks ended October 23 increased at low single-digit rates. In the five weeks of the fourth quarter, our U.K. STRs have decreased at a mid single-digit rate. In the U.S. for the full weeks ended October 23, MillerCoors STRs increased slightly. As always, please keep in mind that these numbers represent only a small portion of the fourth quarter, and trends could change in the weeks ahead. 
In the area of cost outlet by business, in Canada, we expect our full year 2010 cost of goods sold per hectoliter to decrease at a low single-digit rate in local currency. Nonetheless, we do not expect our cost of goods trend to be as favorable in the fourth quarter as it was in the first three quarters of this year. In the U.K., we expect cost of goods per hectoliter of our own brands to increase at mid- single-digit rate in the fourth quarter in local currency. Drivers include the step up in the defying benefit pension expense this year, cycling a mark-to-market credit on natural gas hedges in 2009 and a shift in our sales mix towards the high cost of premise channel, partially offset by cost savings in input cost deflation. 
In the U.S., MillerCoors successfully completed initial product transitions within its national brewing network with more of the company's beer now brewed closer to customers. Going forward, the U.S. team will continue to focus on further optimization to peak season to non-peak season sourcing changes as well as opportunities for increased efficiencies or new capability to capital projects. We continue to expect U.K. cost per hectoliter to be up at a low single-digit rate for the full year of 2010 and approximately flat for the fourth quarter. 
So to summarize our discussion today. Molson Coors achieved strong financial results in the third quarter. Despite the substantial challenges that a weak global economy has presented to our company during the past several quarters, we stayed very sharply focused on our strategies of building brands, driving value from innovation and delivering on our cost-saving commitments. As a result in the third quarter, we grew profits at a double-digit rate. We include margins, we generated substantial cash and we strengthened our balance sheet for our shareholders. 
Now before we start the Q&A portion of the call, three quick comments. First, our prepared remarks today will be on our website for your reference within a couple of hours this afternoon. Also 2:00 p.m. Eastern Time today, our Investor Relations team, led by Dave Dunnewald, will host a follow-up conference call, essentially a working structure for analysts and investors who have additional questions regarding our quarterly results. That call will also be available to you to hear via webcast on our website. 
Secondly, we look forward to pushing many of you in London in December 1 for our 2010 U.K. Analyst and Investor Day. This meeting will provide a strategic update regarding our global business, along with a more detailed view of our U.K. business and the U.K. Beer industry. 
Thirdly, on November 3 and December 2, we will cosponsor with SABMiller two regional seminars focused exclusively on the MillerCoors business. The November 13 meeting, we'll be in London. On the December 2nd meeting, we'll be in New York. All of these analyst days and seminars will be audio webcast for those of you who could not attend the meetings in person. Please contact Dave Dunnewald if you'd reply for more details. 
At this point, Devon, could you please open it up for questions?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, on Canada, it sounds like the industry volume softened in the third quarter. Some of that may have been weather-driven. But even in October, as I look at the comparison a year ago, I think October was down high single digits last year. So I'm just
componenttext: First, on Canada, it sounds like the industry volume softened in the third quarter. Some of that may have been weather-driven. But even in October, as I look at the comparison a year ago, I think October was down high single digits last year. So I'm just wondering if there's anything to sort of point to in terms of what's causing the industry softness in Canada. And then secondly, on your brands, it sounds like Coors Light and Molson Coors, the two of the established brands were down in the quarter. You commented on adjusting your volume priority and maybe you can elaborate on what that means.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, Judy. It's Dave Perkins. On the industry performance, what we saw in Q3 was really a drop-off in September. We did have very bad labor day weekend weather, and we have that weather through Western Canada during the quarter. That seems to be a k
componenttext: Yes. Sure, Judy. It's Dave Perkins. On the industry performance, what we saw in Q3 was really a drop-off in September. We did have very bad labor day weekend weather, and we have that weather through Western Canada during the quarter. That seems to be a key factor note that the economy continues to weigh on people as well, so we see consumer consciousness continuing and unemployment is fairly stable in the 8% range in Canada. So that's a factor. I think as we look forward on sort of the trend, last year was down 1.9% in Q4. So I think you need to consider that as you look forward. Related to Coors Light Canadian, what we did in Ontario, and this was really focused in Ontario, is adjusted our pricing volume priorities. And so we made some past strategy changes. And the net results, that was an increase in the net price to consumers, and that really is reflected in the volume trend that we've seen. We continue to feel very, very positive about what we're seeing on an underlying basis in Canadian Coors Light. I think the brand equity is strong. The reaction we're seeing from consumers to our programming is very strong, so we're feeling good there.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, Stewart, on the Foster's total return swap, so is it your attention to basically close out the remaining position before January 2011? And then if that's the case, where should be the cash impact there?
componenttext: And then, Stewart, on the Foster's total return swap, so is it your attention to basically close out the remaining position before January 2011? And then if that's the case, where should be the cash impact there?

componenttext: Judy, so the answer to your question in short is yes. Understand that we have used some derivative -- we've used the derivative strategy to lock in a range, our potential benefit. And really, I can't give you a cash number because that will depend on how the stock price turns out within that derivative color.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then maybe just more broadly speaking, obviously, you've had this position now for a couple of years or so. So what have you learned through that process? And as you think about the Australian market, what is your updated thinking in terms of your opp
componenttext: And then maybe just more broadly speaking, obviously, you've had this position now for a couple of years or so. So what have you learned through that process? And as you think about the Australian market, what is your updated thinking in terms of your opportunity in that market?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Judy, I'll take that if it's okay. I think let me take this off. We're pretty clear that we said we found the Australian market interest and we saw the exposure that we had to the swap, Davis. I think really three things. One, it was very flexible. S
componenttext: Yes, Judy, I'll take that if it's okay. I think let me take this off. We're pretty clear that we said we found the Australian market interest and we saw the exposure that we had to the swap, Davis. I think really three things. One, it was very flexible. Secondly, it was extremely low risk as far as we were concerned as a business. And thirdly, Davis, the opportunity to actually increase our exposure decreased our move outs. And I think we decided that we no longer wanted the exposures or the swap. I think that's just coincided with us being able to unwind it, and also at the same time realize a cash benefit for the shareholders. So I think that worked really well, and I think our definition of our exposure to the swap has really worked out exactly as we said. As far as the Australian going forward is concerned, same store markets will continue to look at it. We'll continue to examine it, and if there are any opportunities that we think we want to take advantage of there or indeed anywhere else, we would act accordingly.

componenttext: Yes, look, I mean, weak's not a big driver of cost for us. It's certainly grain costs have gone up. But I would -- as of my comment in the past, our value is an important ingredient. But if you looked at the current prices, they're not above where they were in the 2007 sort of time frame. So hopefully that helps.

componenttext: Well, the way I characterize Québec is very stable on the pricing front, so what we did see in the third quarter was a number of weeks, where some of the major retailers actually brought their beer prices up above minimum price. headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: You talked a little bit about the uses of cash, and I guess can you just go through -- I think you said best interest of shareholders. So can you just sort of give us an idea of what you mean by best interest? And then also, kind of prioritize what you're
componenttext: You talked a little bit about the uses of cash, and I guess can you just go through -- I think you said best interest of shareholders. So can you just sort of give us an idea of what you mean by best interest? And then also, kind of prioritize what you're thinking right now.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, look, I mean, our prioritization hasn't changed, and our thinking hasn't changed. It's always been consistent. And that really is that our cash flow falls into three big buckets. One, investing in the business. You've certainly seen a lot of that ove
componenttext: Yes, look, I mean, our prioritization hasn't changed, and our thinking hasn't changed. It's always been consistent. And that really is that our cash flow falls into three big buckets. One, investing in the business. You've certainly seen a lot of that over the last couple of years, most recently with the consummation of the joint venture in China. And we've seen -- the second allocation that we looked at is being taken care of the balance sheet. We certainly gone up to that area this year, a reduction of almost $100 million related to some Brazilian tax liabilities, some historic tension to pensions. We called out that as we look at this fourth quarter, we are in the process of some detailed examination of some of the pensions plans, and we expect by end of the fourth quarter to add some clarity around a potential pension contributions. And then of course, we've seen a fairly large increase in our dividend over the last few years, and we continue to look at options around giving cash back to shareholders. We don't get all of those options from the perspective of what do we think is in the best interest, long-term interest of our shareholders, and we use that to prioritize the specifics of our cash use. And as always, we consult with our board on a quarterly basis with respect to that prioritizaton.

componenttextpreview: Before we get started, I want to paraphrase the company's Safe Harbor language. Some of the discussion today may include forward-looking statements. Actual results could differ materially from what the company projects today, so please refer to its most r
componenttext:
Before we get started, I want to paraphrase the company's Safe Harbor language. Some of the discussion today may include forward-looking statements. Actual results could differ materially from what the company projects today, so please refer to its most recent 10-K and 10-Q filings for a more complete description of factors that could affect these projections. The company does not undertake to publicly update forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. You should not place undue reliance on forward-looking statements, which speak only as of the date they are made.
Regarding any non-U.S. GAAP measures that may be discussed during the call and from time to time by the company's executives in discussing the company's performance, please visit the website, www.molsoncoors.com, and click on the Financial Reporting tab of the Investor Relations page for the reconciliation of these measures to the nearest U.S. GAAP results.
So now I'd like to turn the call over to Mr. Dave Dunnewald, VP President (sic) [Vice President], Investor Relations. Mr. Dunnewald, you may go ahead.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Devin, and welcome, everybody, to Molson Coors Brewing Company's Third Quarter Earnings Follow-up Session Conference Call. The purpose of this call is to address as many additional earnings-related questions as possible, following our regular E
componenttext:
Thank you, Devin, and welcome, everybody, to Molson Coors Brewing Company's Third Quarter Earnings Follow-up Session Conference Call. The purpose of this call is to address as many additional earnings-related questions as possible, following our regular Earnings Conference Call with Peter Swinburn, Stewart Glendinning and our business units CEOs earlier today. 
We will use the standard question-and-answer format, and we anticipate that the call will last less than an hour. So let's get started. 
With me on the call are Greg Snyder, Group Manager of Global Forecasting and Analysis; Steve Hills, Group Manager of SEC Reporting; Spencer Cher [ph], Finance Forecasting Manager; Mark Sacks [ph], Senior Director of Tax; Julio Ramirez, Global Treasurer; and Mark Ingebritson, Assistant Treasurer. 
As Peter Swinburn mentioned on our regular earnings call earlier today, Molson Coors achieved strong financial results in the third quarter. Despite the substantial challenges that the weak global economy has presented our company during the past several quarters, we have stayed sharply focused on our strategies of building brand, driving value from innovation and delivering on our cost-savings commitments. As a result, in the third quarter, we grew profits at a double-digit rate, improved margins, generated substantial cash, and strengthened our balance sheet for our shareholders. 
With that, I'd like to now open it up for the questions you have. Devin?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it'll help if I give you our philosophy around free cash flow. And it's underlying free cash flow, so we do make some adjustments to it. Essentially, what we're doing is trying to give a sense of all of the cash that we can generate as a comp
componenttext: Yes, I think it'll help if I give you our philosophy around free cash flow. And it's underlying free cash flow, so we do make some adjustments to it. Essentially, what we're doing is trying to give a sense of all of the cash that we can generate as a company that's available for us to make decisions around. So for example, one-off stuff like the loan that MillerCoors settled or essentially collected from past, we get 42% of that. That's clearly a onetime thing because they wiped out the loan. But it's a source of cash that we can use in the business or to grow the business or to return, to strengthen our balance sheet or to return to shareholders. So you can see that any source of cash we will count in the free cash flow measure at the end of the year. And we increased it primarily from the earlier goal of $760 million, we increased it up to $900 million this quarter because primarily of some of these onetime things that we don't expect to repeat. And from that free cash flow, we make decisions around things like pension contributions, or do we set up a joint venture and buy a controlling interest in a brewery in China, things like that. So I think that gives you a perspective around cash flow. Fourth quarter pension. We haven't said how much we think that could be. What we have said is at the end of '09, the last time we did the full annual evaluation which normally is just once a year, we had unfunded liabilities in our defined benefit plans of about $885 million. And some of that was driven by historically low interest rates, to be sure. Obviously, equity values play into our funded status and a number of other factors, including what the liabilities are. So we're going to look at that unfunded liability position and see whether or not there's an opportunity to close a part of that. But we have not made the decisions around what that looks like, and so I can't really provide further guidance, except to say that it would not make sense for us to close all of that gap via contributions. On your last question...

componenttext: As I mentioned in the answer to the first question, when we talk about underlying free cash flow, that's essentially a collection of all the sources of cash and obviously, some outflows, too. When we talk about -- or I'm sorry. Once we've accumulated the underlying free cash flow, then we have decisions that we can make about how to use that. And this voluntary accelerated type of contribution would be one of those incremental uses that's not mandated. It's a decision that we make to drive shareholder value. That make sense?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: Yes.

We haven't said where the derivatives essentially lock in that profit, but you can tell it is a profit we're talking about. And it is cash flow from these cash-settled total return swaps. The only sort of milepost, or a bit of information beyond that perspective, is that we settled 16 million shares in the third quarter -- or I should say 16 million shares worth of swaps expired or matured. And that was worth a gain of about $11 million and change.

componenttext: Yes, that will have to be baked into our normal tax calculation, and there are a lot of things that go into that. But yes, it's more income. componenttext: So if you weigh those, you get 5 3/4% of convertible, CAD $900 million at the 5% notes that Mark mentioned. And so yes, you'd get into the low-fives percent on a blended basis without the $500 million that we just issued. So obviously, that bring that down a little bit.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: My question relates to your comments on the earlier call about higher packaging costs. You guys are taking the price increases at the sub-premium, trying to fill the gap up to the premium. As the consumer straight up, are you seeing any type of mix shift
componenttext: My question relates to your comments on the earlier call about higher packaging costs. You guys are taking the price increases at the sub-premium, trying to fill the gap up to the premium. As the consumer straight up, are you seeing any type of mix shift back towards glass which would cause packaging costs to go up a little bit? And then also, what is the mix right now of glass versus can in the U.S.?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right, when consumers trade up, which is what we're seeing if you net it all out, that's what we're seeing in the U.S. And it's a modest trend, but it's happening. That would tend to move toward bottle, But you also see some movement toward draft within t
componenttext: Right, when consumers trade up, which is what we're seeing if you net it all out, that's what we're seeing in the U.S. And it's a modest trend, but it's happening. That would tend to move toward bottle, But you also see some movement toward draft within the total mix. I'm thinking specifically of Blue Moon and [indiscernible], when I'm speaking to that. If you net all that out and look at packaging costs on the whole, I'd call that a minimal factor. One other factor that you'd want to put on there, though, is some of the packaging innovations that we are rolling out into the marketplace, they do have a cost. And those would be rolled into any statement, like we have seen or sustained higher packaging costs in the quarter. That would also be driven by some of those innovative packaging configurations that we've been rolling out. They do process something -- usually not a lot per unit, but that would be another factor.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. And what's the mix in cans versus bottle?
componenttext: Yes. And what's the mix in cans versus bottle?

componenttext: Those percentages don't move much. There's a little bit of movement seasonally. We sell more cans in the summer than we do in the winter, for example, but even that is not a dramatic difference. And certainly, on a year-to-year basis, generally speaking, those percentages move much less than 1% per year. In fact, I haven't seen them move 1% in a number of years.

componenttext: Well, you just talked about $3 million, I guess, of costs coming back in the fourth quarter. It seem to be most specifically on -- basically, on the U.K. business. And then there's a separate comment that,  effectively, inventory that was built at the wholesale level in the third quarter in the U.S. was coming out of the fourth. But I just wanted to confirm, the $3 million was sort of isolated to the U.K., and the shipment timing is sort of a different issue or a different impact?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm glad you asked about that. Yes, roughly $15 million of factors that we do not expect to repeat or we expect to reverse, those are two different things, that we saw in the third quarter. And this is a number that Stewart provided earlier. As he sa
componenttext: Yes, I'm glad you asked about that. Yes, roughly $15 million of factors that we do not expect to repeat or we expect to reverse, those are two different things, that we saw in the third quarter. And this is a number that Stewart provided earlier. As he said, about $3 million of that $15 million are items that we expect to reverse which, obviously, has roughly doubled the impact on the fourth quarter. The $3 million of reversal items are roughly evenly split between the U.K. and, as you said, some marketing expense there. And then also, though, the inventory dynamics in the U.S. market also -- obviously, it'll depend on what the distributors end up doing. It'll depend on what the consumer pull is on our brands and the ability of breweries to meet demand and things like that. You have to count all that in. But as best as we can tell, we'll see a bit of a reversal of the inventory build that we saw in the third quarter. Now it's relatively modest, just $1 million or $2 million worth at our 42% rate. But we didn't want to highlight that for people because they're obviously going to see the gap between STWs [sales-to-wholesalers] and STRs [sales-to-retailers] in the U.S. So those are the two reversal factors. All the rest of the $15 million that Stewart talked about are really elements that benefited the third quarter that we do not expect to benefit future quarters, and we referenced each of those within the business units as we went through the results. And then let's see -- so getting back to the next-generation cost savings, we only provide rough guidance on that. But roughly 2/3 or so of those would be cost of goods-related, supply chain-related, that kind of thing. And then the rest would be more in the MG&A line.

componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I guess, I would take you back, I know it's a long time, but take you back two years. And really for all of the last two years, we've been talking about the Foster's swap positions along the lines of -- because we've got the question quite a bi
componenttext: Yes. Well, I guess, I would take you back, I know it's a long time, but take you back two years. And really for all of the last two years, we've been talking about the Foster's swap positions along the lines of -- because we've got the question quite a bit: Why did you take out the swap positions related to Foster's? And we said, "Well, while we study the market and the company, we wanted to gain some exposure to their stock price at an attractive price." And that's important. And we wanted to do it in a way that was flexible, gave us maximum flexibility, minimal cash upfront, minimal FX exposure. And really, the swap position has given us that all this time. And so we made the decision that this was the best time to unwind the swap position, and I mean the best time in the interest of our shareholders. And as a result, we're anticipating a book and cash gain on the swap position.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010

componenttext: Yes. I would say, it sounds you're referring specifically to MillerCoors. They have consistently exceeded both timing. Well, let's say timing on all of their cost-reduction programs. So they're ahead on synergies, and they're earlier on the next program. They understand and as does the rest of Molson Coors, I mean, all of Molson Coors as well, the other parent company. We understand the importance of hitting these targets on cost savings are critical to providing resources to grow the business and also to grow the bottom line. And as a result, we have met or exceeded all of our goals around cost savings, both at MillerCoors and at Molson Coors.
