componenttext: So if you weigh those, you get 5 3/4% of convertible, CAD $900 million at the 5% notes that Mark mentioned. And so yes, you'd get into the low-fives percent on a blended basis without the $500 million that we just issued. So obviously, that’d bring that down a little bit.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mike Alkin of Knott Partners.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike Alkin of Knott Partners.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: My question relates to your comments on the earlier call about higher packaging costs. You guys are taking the price increases at the sub-premium, trying to fill the gap up to the premium. As the consumer straight up, are you seeing any type of mix shift
componenttext: My question relates to your comments on the earlier call about higher packaging costs. You guys are taking the price increases at the sub-premium, trying to fill the gap up to the premium. As the consumer straight up, are you seeing any type of mix shift back towards glass which would cause packaging costs to go up a little bit? And then also, what is the mix right now of glass versus can in the U.S.?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right, when consumers trade up, which is what we're seeing if you net it all out, that's what we're seeing in the U.S. And it's a modest trend, but it's happening. That would tend to move toward bottle, but you also see some movement toward draft within t
componenttext: Right, when consumers trade up, which is what we're seeing if you net it all out, that's what we're seeing in the U.S. And it's a modest trend, but it's happening. That would tend to move toward bottle, but you also see some movement toward draft within the total mix. I'm thinking specifically of Blue Moon and Leinenkugel, when I'm speaking to that. If you net all that out and look at packaging costs on the whole, I'd call that a minimal factor. One other factor that you'd want to put on there, though, is some of the packaging innovations that we are rolling out into the marketplace, they do have a cost. And those would be rolled into any statement, like we have seen or sustained higher packaging costs in the quarter. That would also be driven by some of those innovative packaging configurations that we've been rolling out. They do cost something -- usually not a lot per unit, but that would be another factor.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. And what's the mix in cans versus bottle?
componenttext: Yes. And what's the mix in cans versus bottle?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let's see, we are just under 60% cans, 10% draft and therefore, around 30% bottles.
componenttext: Let's see, we are just under 60% cans, 10% draft and therefore, around 30% bottles.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: And David, what's the bottle peak when things are going very well?
componenttext: And David, what's the bottle peak when things are going very well?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, a bottle peak?
componenttext: I'm sorry, a bottle peak?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, when business is strong and volumes are strong. And if business comes back, what would you expect to see the bottles get to as a percentage?
componenttext: Yes, when business is strong and volumes are strong. And if business comes back, what would you expect to see the bottles get to as a percentage?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Those percentages don't move much. There's a little bit of movement seasonally. We sell more cans in the summer than we do in the winter, for example, but even that is not a dramatic difference. And certainly, on a year-to-year basis, generally speaking,
componenttext: Those percentages don't move much. There's a little bit of movement seasonally. We sell more cans in the summer than we do in the winter, for example, but even that is not a dramatic difference. And certainly, on a year-to-year basis, generally speaking, those percentages move much less than 1% per year. In fact, I haven't seen them move 1% in a number of years.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, you just talked about $3 million, I guess, of costs coming back in the fourth quarter. It seemed to be most specifically on -- basically, on the U.K. business. And then there's a separate comment that, effectively, inventory that was built at the wh
componenttext: Well, you just talked about $3 million, I guess, of costs coming back in the fourth quarter. It seemed to be most specifically on -- basically, on the U.K. business. And then there's a separate comment that, effectively, inventory that was built at the wholesale level in the third quarter in the U.S. was coming out of the fourth. But I just wanted to confirm, the $3 million was sort of isolated to the U.K., and the shipment timing is sort of a different issue or a different impact?

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm glad you asked about that. Yes, roughly $15 million of factors that we do not expect to repeat or we expect to reverse, those are two different things, that we saw in the third quarter. And this is a number that Stewart provided earlier. As he sa
componenttext: Yes, I'm glad you asked about that. Yes, roughly $15 million of factors that we do not expect to repeat or we expect to reverse, those are two different things, that we saw in the third quarter. And this is a number that Stewart provided earlier. As he said, about $3 million of that $15 million are items that we expect to reverse which, obviously, has roughly double the impact on the fourth quarter. The $3 million of reversal items are roughly evenly split between the U.K., as you said, some marketing expense there. And then also, though, the inventory dynamics in the U.S. market also -- obviously, it'll depend on what the distributors end up doing. It'll depend on what the consumer pull is on our brands and the ability of breweries to meet demand and things like that. You have to count all that in. But as best as we can tell, we'll see a bit of a reversal of the inventory build that we saw in the third quarter. Now it's relatively modest, just $1 million or $2 million worth at our 42% rate. But we didn't want to highlight that for people because they're obviously going to see the gap between STWs [sales-to-wholesalers] and STRs [sales-to-retailers] in the U.S. So those are the two reversal factors. All the rest of the $15 million that Stewart talked about are really elements that benefited the third quarter that we do not expect to benefit future quarters, and we referenced each of those within the business units as we went through the results. And then let's see -- so getting back to the next-generation cost savings, we only provide rough guidance on that. But roughly 2/3 or so of those would be cost of goods-related, supply chain-related, that kind of thing. And then the rest would be more in the MG&A line.

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Rob Porter [ph] of Louis Sales [ph].

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I guess, I would take you back, I know it's a long time, but take you back two years. And really for all of the last two years, we've been talking about the Foster's swap positions along the lines of -- because we've got the question quite a bi
componenttext: Yes. Well, I guess, I would take you back, I know it's a long time, but take you back two years. And really for all of the last two years, we've been talking about the Foster's swap positions along the lines of -- because we've got the question quite a bit: Why did you take out the swap positions related to Foster's? And we said, "Well, while we study the market and the company, we wanted to gain some exposure to their stock price at an attractive price." And that's important. And we wanted to do it in a way that was flexible, gave us maximum flexibility, minimal cash upfront, minimal FX exposure. And really, the swap position has given us that all this time. And so we made the decision that this was the best time to unwind the swap position, and I mean the best time in the interest of our shareholders. And as a result, we're anticipating a book and cash gain on the swap position.

headline: Molson Coors Brewing Company, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say, it sounds like you're referring specifically to MillerCoors. They have consistently exceeded both timing. Well, let's say timing on all of their cost-reduction programs. So they're ahead on synergies, and they're earlier on the next prog
componenttext: Yes. I would say, it sounds like you're referring specifically to MillerCoors. They have consistently exceeded both timing. Well, let's say timing on all of their cost-reduction programs. So they're ahead on synergies, and they're earlier on the next program. They understand and as does the rest of Molson Coors, I mean, all of Molson Coors as well, the other parent company. We understand the importance of hitting these targets on cost savings are critical to providing resources to grow the business and also to grow the bottom line. And as a result, we have met or exceeded all of our goals around cost savings, both at MillerCoors and at Molson Coors.

Thank you, again, and have a great day.
